mn109:0.2.eng: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

mn109:1.1.comm: This discourse is also found at SN 22.82, with only minor differences in readings.

mn109:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
mn109:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.

mn109:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā tadahuposathe pannarase puṇṇāya puṇṇamāya rattiyā bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto abbhokāse nisinno hoti.
mn109:2.1.eng: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.

mn109:3.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ cīvaraṃ katvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn109:3.1.eng: Then one of the mendicants got up from their seat, arranged their robe over one shoulder, raised their joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,

mn109:3.2.pli: “Puccheyyāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ kiñcideva desaṃ, sace me bhagavā okāsaṃ karoti pañhassa veyyākaraṇāyā”ti.
mn109:3.2.eng: “Sir, I’d like to ask the Buddha about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”
mn109:3.2.comm: The commentary says that he asked these questions in order to educate his students. This seems probable in view of the fact that the sequence of questions is structured in a way that is clearly purposeful.

mn109:3.3.pli: “Tena hi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, sake āsane nisīditvā puccha yadākaṅkhasī”ti.
mn109:3.3.eng: “Well then, mendicant, take your own seat and ask what you wish.”

mn109:3.4.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu sake āsane nisīditvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn109:3.4.eng: That mendicant took his seat and said to the Buddha:

mn109:4.1.eng: “Sir, are these the five grasping aggregates:

mn109:4.2.eng: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”

mn109:4.5.pli: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṃ uttariṃ pañhaṃ pucchi:
mn109:4.5.eng: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. Then he asked another question:
mn109:4.5.comm: The remainder of the discourse omits these responses, but they are mostly included in the parallel (see note on SN 22.82:4.2).

mn109:5.1.eng: “But sir, what is the root of these five grasping aggregates?”

mn109:5.2.eng: “These five grasping aggregates are rooted in desire.”
mn109:5.2.comm: “Desire” (chanda) is the fundamental driving force underlying all manifestations of the aggregates. It is the same as “craving” (taṇhā).

mn109:6.1.pli: “Taṃyeva nu kho, bhante, upādānaṃ te pañcupādānakkhandhā, udāhu aññatra pañcahupādānakkhandhehi upādānan”ti?
mn109:6.1.eng: “But sir, is that grasping the exact same thing as the five grasping aggregates? Or is grasping one thing and the five grasping aggregates another?”

mn109:6.2.pli: “Na kho, bhikkhu, taṃyeva upādānaṃ te pañcupādānakkhandhā, nāpi aññatra pañcahupādānakkhandhehi upādānaṃ.

mn109:6.3.pli: Yo kho, bhikkhu, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu chandarāgo taṃ tattha upādānan”ti.
mn109:6.3.eng: The desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates is the grasping there.”

mn109:7.1.eng: “But sir, can there be disparity in desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates?”

mn109:7.4.pli: ‘evaṃrūpo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃvedano siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃsañño siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃsaṅkhāro siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānaṃ, evaṃviññāṇo siyaṃ anāgatamaddhānan’ti.
mn109:7.4.eng: ‘In the future, may I be of such form, such feeling, such perception, such choices, and such consciousness!’
mn109:7.4.comm: This assumes the persistence of a “self” through time.

mn109:7.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, siyā pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu chandarāgavemattatā”ti.
mn109:7.5.eng: That’s how there can be disparity in desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates.”

mn109:8.1.eng: “Sir, what is the scope of the term ‘aggregates’ as applied to the aggregates?”
mn109:8.1.comm: The question is whether there is anything outside the aggregates.

mn109:8.2.pli: “Yaṃ kiñci, bhikkhu, rūpaṃ—atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā, oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā, hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā, yaṃ dūre santike vā—ayaṃ rūpakkhandho.
mn109:8.2.eng: “Any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of form.

mn109:8.3.pli: Yā kāci vedanā—atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā, oḷārikā vā sukhumā vā, hīnā vā paṇītā vā, yā dūre santike vā—ayaṃ vedanākkhandho.
mn109:8.3.eng: Any kind of feeling at all …

mn109:8.4.pli: Yā kāci saññā—atītānāgatapaccuppannā …pe… yā dūre santike vā—ayaṃ saññākkhandho.
mn109:8.4.eng: Any kind of perception at all …

mn109:8.5.pli: Ye keci saṅkhārā—atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā, oḷārikā vā sukhumā vā, hīnā vā paṇītā vā, ye dūre santike vā—ayaṃ saṅkhārakkhandho.
mn109:8.5.eng: Any kind of choices at all …

mn109:8.6.pli: Yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ—atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā, oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā, hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā, yaṃ dūre santike vā—ayaṃ viññāṇakkhandho.
mn109:8.6.eng: Any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of consciousness.

mn109:8.7.pli: Ettāvatā kho, bhikkhu, khandhānaṃ khandhādhivacanaṃ hotī”ti.
mn109:8.7.eng: That’s the scope of the term ‘aggregates’ as applied to the aggregates.”
mn109:8.7.comm: That is to say, the term “aggregate” (khandha) is a collective term for all instances of this kind of phenomenon.

mn109:9.1.pli: “Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo rūpakkhandhassa paññāpanāya?
mn109:9.1.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why the aggregate of form is found?
mn109:9.1.comm: While the “root” of all aggregates is desire, the question now is the immediate basis of each particular aggregate.

mn109:9.2.pli: Ko hetu ko paccayo vedanākkhandhassa paññāpanāya?
mn109:9.2.eng: What is the cause, what is the reason why the aggregate of feeling …

mn109:9.3.pli: Ko hetu ko paccayo saññākkhandhassa paññāpanāya?

mn109:9.4.pli: Ko hetu ko paccayo saṅkhārakkhandhassa paññāpanāya?

mn109:9.5.pli: Ko hetu ko paccayo viññāṇakkhandhassa paññāpanāyā”ti?

mn109:9.6.pli: “Cattāro kho, bhikkhu, mahābhūtā hetu, cattāro mahābhūtā paccayo rūpakkhandhassa paññāpanāya.
mn109:9.6.eng: “The four principal states are the reason why the aggregate of form is found.

mn109:9.7.pli: Phasso hetu, phasso paccayo vedanākkhandhassa paññāpanāya.
mn109:9.7.eng: Contact is the reason why the aggregates of feeling,
mn109:9.7.comm: In dependent origination, “contact” (phassa) is the immediate condition for “feeling” (vedanā). But contact can also be regarded as the immediate condition for all three: feeling, perception, and choices (eg. SN 35.93:1.14). These things are always active in consciousness, so they can be treated as simultaneous, as arising in sequence, or as mutually conditioning.

mn109:9.8.pli: Phasso hetu, phasso paccayo saññākkhandhassa paññāpanāya.
mn109:9.8.comm: Feeling and “perception” (saññā) are closely connected, since how we feel conditions how we recognize and interpret. While contact directly underlies feeling, perception works so quickly that is can be included as a direct consequence as well.

mn109:9.9.pli: Phasso hetu, phasso paccayo saṅkhārakkhandhassa paññāpanāya.
mn109:9.9.comm: Likewise with “choices” (saṅkhārā), which are also part of the complex of reactivity that normally take effect immediately. For example, suppose we try eating a berry in the forest. “Contact” with its bitter taste “feels” unpleasant, so we “perceive” it as poisonous, and “choose” to spit it out.

mn109:9.10.pli: Nāmarūpaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, nāmarūpaṃ paccayo viññāṇakkhandhassa paññāpanāyā”ti.
mn109:9.10.eng: Name and form are the reasons why the aggregate of consciousness is found.”
mn109:9.10.comm: Normally in dependent origination, it is consciousness that is a condition for name and form. The presentation here assumes their mutual conditioning, as spelled out at DN 15:22.1. Name and form are the embryo that supports consciousness in the process of rebirth, while the physical body with its senses, and the psychological functions included under “name” continue to evolve and grow with consciousness through life.

mn109:10.1.eng: “But sir, how does substantialist view come about?”

mn109:10.2.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṃ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto
mn109:10.2.eng: “It’s when an unlearned ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.

mn109:10.3.pli: rūpaṃ attato samanupassati rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ attani vā rūpaṃ rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ;
mn109:10.3.eng: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

mn109:10.4.pli: vedanaṃ attato samanupassati vedanāvantaṃ vā attānaṃ attani vā vedanaṃ vedanāya vā attānaṃ;
mn109:10.4.eng: They regard feeling as self, self as having feeling, feeling in self, or self in feeling.

mn109:10.5.pli: saññaṃ attato samanupassati saññāvantaṃ vā attānaṃ attani vā saññaṃ saññāya vā attānaṃ;
mn109:10.5.eng: They regard perception as self, self as having perception, perception in self, or self in perception.

mn109:10.6.pli: saṅkhāre attato samanupassati saṅkhāravantaṃ vā attānaṃ attani vā saṅkhāre saṅkhāresu vā attānaṃ;
mn109:10.6.eng: They regard choices as self, self as having choices, choices in self, or self in choices.

mn109:10.7.pli: viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ attani vā viññāṇaṃ viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
mn109:10.7.eng: They regard consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

mn109:10.8.eng: That’s how substantialist view comes about.”
mn109:10.8.comm: That is to say, the “substantialist” view takes the aggregates, or one of them, to be a “substantial reality” that is identified with the self. Such views are created each time we think or attach to the aggregates as a self.

mn109:11.1.eng: “But sir, how does substantialist view not come about?”

mn109:11.2.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako ariyānaṃ dassāvī ariyadhammassa kovido ariyadhamme suvinīto sappurisānaṃ dassāvī sappurisadhammassa kovido sappurisadhamme suvinīto
mn109:11.2.eng: “It’s when a learned noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons.

mn109:11.3.pli: na rūpaṃ attato samanupassati na rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ na attani vā rūpaṃ na rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ;
mn109:11.3.eng: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

mn109:11.4.pli: na vedanaṃ attato samanupassati na vedanāvantaṃ vā attānaṃ na attani vā vedanaṃ na vedanāya vā attānaṃ;
mn109:11.4.eng: They don’t regard feeling as self, self as having feeling, feeling in self, or self in feeling.

mn109:11.5.pli: na saññaṃ attato samanupassati na saññāvantaṃ vā attānaṃ na attani vā saññaṃ na saññāya vā attānaṃ;
mn109:11.5.eng: They don’t regard perception as self, self as having perception, perception in self, or self in perception.

mn109:11.6.pli: na saṅkhāre attato samanupassati na saṅkhāravantaṃ vā attānaṃ na attani vā saṅkhāre na saṅkhāresu vā attānaṃ;
mn109:11.6.eng: They don’t regard choices as self, self as having choices, choices in self, or self in choices.

mn109:11.7.pli: na viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati na viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ na attani vā viññāṇaṃ na viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
mn109:11.7.eng: They don’t regard consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

mn109:11.8.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, sakkāyadiṭṭhi na hotī”ti.
mn109:11.8.eng: That’s how substantialist view does not come about.”
mn109:11.8.comm: Since substantialist view is itself a conditioned phenomenon, it can only continue to exist if it is continually reinforced. Without it, like a fire without a constant supply of fuel, it falters and goes out.

mn109:12.1.pli: “Ko nu kho, bhante, rūpe assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ?
mn109:12.1.eng: “Sir, what’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to form,
mn109:12.1.comm: We have met these questions before at MN 13:6.2. Here they build on the previous section by showing a strategy for how to stop identifying them as the substantial reality underlying the self. This can be used as the basis for a contemplative insight meditation.

mn109:12.2.pli: Ko vedanāya assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ?

mn109:12.3.pli: Ko saññāya assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ?

mn109:12.4.pli: Ko saṅkhāresu assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ?

mn109:12.5.pli: Ko viññāṇe assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan”ti?

mn109:12.6.pli: “Yaṃ kho, bhikkhu, rūpaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ rūpe assādo.
mn109:12.6.eng: “The pleasure and happiness that arise from form: this is its gratification.

mn109:12.7.pli: Yaṃ rūpaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, ayaṃ rūpe ādīnavo.
mn109:12.7.eng: That form is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

mn109:12.8.pli: Yo rūpe chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ rūpe nissaraṇaṃ.
mn109:12.8.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for form: this is its escape.

mn109:12.9.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling …

mn109:12.12.pli: viññāṇaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ viññāṇe assādo.

mn109:12.13.pli: Yaṃ viññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, ayaṃ viññāṇe ādīnavo.
mn109:12.13.eng: That consciousness is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

mn109:12.14.pli: Yo viññāṇe chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ viññāṇe nissaraṇan”ti.
mn109:12.14.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for consciousness: this is its escape.”

mn109:13.1.pli: “Kathaṃ pana, bhante, jānato kathaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti?
mn109:13.1.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs?”
mn109:13.1.comm: From meditative contemplation, the question now turns to realization. The Buddha’s response makes it clear he is now speaking of the penetrative understanding of the aggregates that arises at stream-entry at least. The “underlying tendency to conceit”, however, is only fully overcome by the arahant. | “I-making” (ahaṅkāra) emphasizes the active role of the mind in creating a sense of self through its thoughts, habits, and desires. This is in contrast with the English notion of “ego”, which presents self as a given construct. | “Mine-making” (mamaṅkāra) is the propensity of the mind to appropriate things as possessions. | “All signs” (sabbanimitta) are the “features” (also nimitta) that characterize sensory stimulation (eg. MN 112:15.1).

mn109:13.2.pli: “Yaṃ kiñci, bhikkhu, rūpaṃ—atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā—sabbaṃ rūpaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
mn109:13.2.eng: “One truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn109:13.3.eng: One truly sees any kind of feeling …

mn109:13.6.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ—atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā—sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
mn109:13.6.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near, all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn109:13.7.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, jānato evaṃ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti.
mn109:13.7.eng: That’s how to know and see so that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs.”

mn109:14.1.pli: Atha kho aññatarassa bhikkhuno evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
mn109:14.1.eng: Now at that time one of the mendicants had the thought,

mn109:14.2.pli: “iti kira, bho, rūpaṃ anattā, vedanā anattā, saññā anattā, saṅkhārā anattā, viññāṇaṃ anattā;
mn109:14.2.eng: “So it seems, worthy sir, that form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are not-self.
mn109:14.2.comm: In his mind, the monk addresses the Buddha with “worthy sir” (bho), which is a signature of the brahmins (MN 98:11.3). Small wonder he still assumes a self.

mn109:14.3.eng: Then how will the deeds done by not-self affect the self?”
mn109:14.3.comm: This monk, missing the point, thinks not-self means he can escape moral responsibility. A theory of self assumes a continuous entity, so that deeds done at one time will affect the same entity at another time. The Buddhist concept, on the other hand, is of a flow, so that, for example, pollution dumped in a stream will affect the river and the sea below, even though they are not materially the “same”.

mn109:14.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassa bhikkhuno cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn109:14.4.eng: But the Buddha, knowing that mendicant’s train of thought, addressed the mendicants:

mn109:14.5.pli: “ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco moghapuriso avidvā avijjāgato taṇhādhipateyyena cetasā satthu sāsanaṃ atidhāvitabbaṃ maññeyya:
mn109:14.5.eng: “It’s possible that some futile person here—unknowing and ignorant, their mind dominated by craving—thinks they can overstep the teacher’s instructions. They think:

mn109:14.6.pli: ‘iti kira, bho, rūpaṃ anattā, vedanā anattā, saññā anattā, saṅkhārā anattā, viññāṇaṃ anattā;
mn109:14.6.eng: ‘So it seems, worthy sir, that form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are not-self.

mn109:14.7.eng: Then how will the deeds done by not-self affect the self?’

mn109:14.8.pli: Paṭivinītā kho me tumhe, bhikkhave, tatra tatra dhammesu.
mn109:14.8.eng: Now, mendicants, you have been educated by me in questioning with regard to all these things in all such cases.
mn109:14.8.comm: Read paṭipucchāvinītā with SN 22.82:13.4. It is the name for the method of questioning the Buddha is about to use. The Buddha does not just state doctrine for his students, he has “educated” (vinīta) them in the methods for learning. Active questioning breaks up long discourses and encourages reflection and articulation.

mn109:15.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn109:15.4.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn109:15.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn109:15.6.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn109:15.7.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn109:16.7.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
mn109:16.7.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

mn109:16.9.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
mn109:16.9.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

mn109:16.10.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

mn109:16.12.pli: “Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā sabbaṃ rūpaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
mn109:16.12.eng: “So you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn109:17.1.eng: You should truly see any kind of feeling …

mn109:17.4.pli: yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
mn109:17.4.eng: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near, all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

mn109:17.5.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati, saññāyapi nibbindati, saṅkhāresupi nibbindati, viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati;
mn109:17.5.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

mn109:18.1.pli: nibbindaṃ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
mn109:18.1.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

mn109:18.2.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
mn109:18.2.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

mn109:18.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn109:18.4.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn109:18.4.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
mn109:18.4.comm: The parallel at SN 22.82:15.1 has a completely different closing passage. Generally speaking, such passages were added at a later date to wrap up the teaching portion, and there is considerable variation within the Pali texts, let alone Chinese and other parallels.

mn109:18.5.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne saṭṭhimattānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsūti.
mn109:18.5.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of sixty mendicants were freed from defilements by not grasping.
